Musical \u2018Voice of city\u2019 entert.description: Nagpur: To take the music lovers on a melodious journey, the karaoke singer club Prafulla Shah organized a programme ‘Voice of city’ at Utkarsh Hall, Mor Hindi Bhavan, Sitabuldi, on Tuesday. Conceptualized by the members of the group including Yogesh Butke, CY Raipure and Sandeep Malik, the show was hosted by Pravin Bhivgade.Most of the songs presented by the artistes were originally sung by legendary singers like Lata Mangeshkar, Mohammed Rafi, Asha Bhosle, Mukesh, Kavita Krishnamurthy and Kishore Kumar.Butke kick-started the event with the peppy number ‘Darde dil darde jigar’ from the movie ‘Karz’ which was followed by a duet performance by Vijaya and Sandeep Malik on ‘Teri yaad aa rahi hai’ from the movie ‘Love Story’. Vaibhav Dashputre mesmerized the audience with his performance on ‘Koi roko na dewaane ko’ from the movie ‘Priyatma’. The next performance by Chanchal Singh on ‘Dewaana mai chala’ which was well-received. The soulful composition ‘Lambi judai’ was rendered by Bhagyashree Kulkarni and went on to perform another duet with Singh on ‘Tip tip barsa paani’ that set the mood right.The artistes engaged the music lovers with evergreen songs like ‘Raat ke humsafar’, ‘Pyaar do pyaar lo’, ‘Sola baras ki baali umar’, ‘Ek pyaar ka nagma hai’, ‘Naino mein badra chhaye’ , ‘Tu tu hai wahi’, ‘Jo tumko ho pasand’ and some others makingthe audience jog down the memory lane.Other singers Aruna Choudhari, Shaila Kachore, Kaushik Pujari and Alpa Tawaliya entertained the gathering.(Reporting by Srishti Sankrit)Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Mahagathbandhan.description: NEW DELHI: Taking a swipe at the grand alliance of opposition parties, finance minister Arun Jaitley on Friday said the 'mahagathbandhan' is a 'non-bandhan', political circus and a recipe for chaos. Several political parties, mostly traditional BJP opponents, have come together to take on the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) in the ensuing general elections beginning April 11. In a blog post, Jaitley said that over the last several months, India was "exhausted" with the talk of a 'Mahagathbandhan'. The rationale, he said, was that Prime Minister Narendra Modi and the BJP were very strong and could not be challenged by individual party. Stressing that Indians judge politicians by their merit and capacity and no longer by any traditional loyalty, he said: "We were promised a 'coalition of rivals' because India had to be saved. We were promised a common minimum agenda. Each leader amongst the aspirant Prime Ministers wanted to become a 'sutradhar' (anchor) of the alliance. He/she would periodically organise shows in his/her State and invite the entire bandwagon." In opposition camp, Jaitley said there is a tussle for leadership as already multiple candidates have made their desire clear to take over the mantle of the leadership. According to him, each one of them is interested to see the strength of the other party's contender depleting and also have high hopes in a chaotic and highly hung Parliament. "He/ she believes that only in a chaotic situation he/she has a chance," said Jaitley, who is heading the BJP's publicity division of the seven-phase Lok Sabha elections. The past track record of such governments in terms of policy, longevity and growth has to be borne in mind, he said adding their track record of corruption is equally well-known. Jaitley further said it is only because of the size of the BJP and clarity on leadership in the last coalition that a successful government was run under Prime Minister Modi. "Today you have no 'gathbandhan' let alone 'mahagathbandhan'. It is a 'non-bandhan'. You have no leader, no programme, no meeting of minds. "Stability, which is paramount, is a major casualty. The only thing in common is negative agenda 'remove one man'. It is a recipe for chaos," he said in the blog titled 'A Political Circus Called 'Mahagathbandhan'. The nominations for the first two phases of polling are over and those for the third phase are about to happen. The results will be announced on May 23. NMC notice to Scania for shifting buses.description: NAGPUR: The Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) city transport department on Tuesday served notice to Swedish bus maker Scania Commercial Vehicles India Private Ltd for moving out its ethanol-run buses from the city without any intimation. The civic body also questioned how Scania dismantled the ethanol fuel dispensing unit at Khapri. TOI had, on Tuesday, reported Scania had shifted 24 of the 25 ethanol buses, probably to Bengaluru, putting paid to NMC’s plan to resume the country’s first green city bus service. Chairman of city transport committee Bunty Kukde conducted an investigation and found only one bus was left in the city. Following Kukde’s directives, city transport manager Shivaji Jagtap sent notice to Torbjorn Glad, CEO of Scania’s special purpose vehicle — SST Sustainable Transport Solutions. “It is a very serious issue that you unilaterally shifted buses from the city. The buses were registered with RTO as public transport vehicles. Therefore, the permission of appropriate authority was mandatory, which was not ensured. Therefore, we will take appropriate action against you after verifying legal provisions,” Jagtap said. Kukde said NMC will inform arbitrator AR Patil about the incident. “Scania had stopped the service unilaterally. NMC had refused to accept termination notice of Scania. It seems the company was not interested in serving the city, local people and country. We will take appropriate action, as we have Scania’s bank guarantee and payment,” he said. BJP List 2019 WB.description: KOLKATA: The BJP in its first list of 28 candidates for West Bengal has pinned hopes on its veterans and defectors from the ruling Trinamool Congress to take on the Mamata Banerjee's government in the state. Of the 28 candidates, nearly 25 are new faces, with a thrust on active political workers rather than greenhorns from the glamour world. The saffron party, which bagged two Lok Sabha seats in the 2014 elections, is now targeting 23 of the state's 42 constituencies. BJP Lok Sabha first full listUnlike the TMC list, which had 18 new faces and a mix of both old-timers and greenhorns, hardcore politicians and personalities from the film industry, the BJP has put faith on its own leaders and defectors from other parties. There are four women candidates and one Muslim nominee in the first list. Of the candidates, five had recently defected to the saffron party from the Trinamool Congress and one from the CPI(M). West Bengal: Track here Lok Sabha elections' full coverageUnion minister and BJP MP from Asansol Lok Sabha constituency Babul Supriyo has been renominated from the same seat and is pitted against actor Moon Moon Sen of the TMC. State BJP president Dilip Ghosh will contest from Medinipur seat against TMC leader Manas Bhunia. BJP national secretary Rahul Sinha will take on TMC heavyweight Sudip Bandopadhyay in Kolkata North Lok Sabha seat. State BJP vice-president and Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose grandnephew, Chandra Kumar Bose will contest from Kolkata South Lok Sabha seat. Former IPS officer Bharati Ghosh, once known to be close to Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee, will be fighting against TMC candidate and actor Dipak Adhikary, popularly known as 'Dev', from Ghatal Lok Sabha constituency. The BJP has fielded former Trinamool Congress MLA Arjun Singh from Barrackpur Lok Sabha seat. Singh, who had recently joined the saffron party, has been pitted against TMCs Dinesh Trivedi. In Coochbebar Lok Sabha seat, the party has fielded former TMC youth leader Nishith Pramanik, while in Jadavpur Lok Sabha seat, expelled TMC MP Anupam Hazra will contest against TMC's Mimi Chakraborty, an actor by profession. Another former TMC MP Soumitra Khan, who joined the BJP in January, has been given ticket from Bishnupur(SC) Lok Sabha seat. Former CPI(M) MLA Khagen Murmu, who too had switched over to the BJP, will contest from Malda North seat and will take on TMCs Mausam Benazir Noor, who had recently defected to the party from the Congress, in Malda Uttar seat. The Lok Sabha elections in the state will be held from April 11 till May 19 in seven phases. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Experts brainstorm over clean air issue.description: NAGPUR: A seminar titled ‘Clearing the air in Nagpur: Strengthening actions through partnerships’, jointly organized by Clean Air Asia (CAA), Nagpur Municipal Corporation and Integrated Programme for Better Air Quality in Asia (IBAQ) provided a platform for a discussion on the Nagpur air action plan which has been recently approved by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB).  The clean air action plan was prepared by Maharashtra Pollution Control Board (MPCB) with support from National Environmental Engineering Research Institute (Neeri) and the NMC has taken up the lead in its implementation. The seminar was inaugurated by mayor Nanda Jichkar and municipal commissioner Abhijit Bangar. Setting the context for the seminar, India director of CAA Prarthana Borah said, “Since the clean air action plan has been approved by the CPCB, it is now time to deliberate over its implementation. The major problem lies in developing cities as there is increased constructional dust and emissions due to improper waste management deteriorate the air quality.” Borah said that the objective of organizing the session was to engage in a discussion regarding sustainable urban development and clean technology for clean air. Bangar emphasized on the need to take account of the vulnerable sections of the city as all localities are not affected equally. He added, “It is high time to start implementation of schemes for the improvement in air quality management. Through this event, an organized effort will be made to retain Nagpur's ‘Green city’ tag and move forward in the direction of maintaining good air quality for future generations.” In her address, Jichkar focused on the regulatory, policy and implementation tactics. She said, “Now that the Smart City project is in full-swing, the hazardous dust particles from constructional activities is a matter of seriousness. I hope, through citizen awareness and government partnership, we derive a concrete solution to mitigate pollution. Neeri has done a great job at creating a road map of the activities that need to be done. With the help of concerned officials and participation of leaders, we will implement strict rules to ensure everyone breathes fresh air.” Leena Buddhe, director at Centre for Sustainable Development (CFSD), urged NGOs to collaborate in implementation of the air action plan for leveraging wider change. AS Harinath, from World Bank, delved deeper into the aspects of implementation strategy of Nagpur air action plan. He said, “Having an action plan is the first step. Our commitment is to build on the government’s action plan. We then need implementation, investment and coordination between a number of agencies.” Representatives from local government, civil society, academia and technology providers engaged in an interactive session where they analysed their roles in the action plan and suggested proposals. BSP List 2019 UP.description: LUCKNOW: The BSP on Friday announced its first list of 11 candidates for the Lok Sabha elections 2019, fielding JD(S) turncoat Kunwar Danish Ali from Amroha. Ali, who was general secretary of the Janata Dal-Secular, quit the party and joined the Bahujan Samaj Party only last week. The BSP also declared Haji Fazulrahman its nominee from Saharanpur, Malook Nagar from Bijnore and Girish Chandra from Nagina, a party release said. Hazi Mohammad Yakoob has been fielded from Meerut, Satbeer Nagar from Gautam Buddh Nagar, Yogesh Verma from Bulandshahr, Ajit Baliyan from Aligarh, Manoj Kumar Soni from Agra, Rajveer Singh from Fatehpur Sikri and Ruchi Veera from Aonla. Mayawati's BSP is contesting 38 of the 80 Lok Sabha constituencies in Uttar Pradesh under the seat-sharing arrangement with Samajwadi Party and the Rashtriya Lok Dal. PM Modi.description: JEYPORE: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Friday said his government had taken measures to set up a 'chowkidar' in space and asked people to vote for a government that can take concrete decisions and not just raise slogans. Launching his campaign in eastern India with a rally in Jeypore area of Odisha's Koraput district, the prime minister said the NDA government wouldn't have been able to do any development work in the country without the support of the people. He sought blessings from his supporters for the 2019 Lok Sabha elections and asserted that the NDA government has left no stone unturned to bring about development in the state. Land, air or space, we had courage to do surgical strikes: PM Modi"The NDA government has been working hard to develop road and rail infrastructure in the state. There is no dearth of funds when it comes to development work in the country. "In the last five years, the government has been able to build homes for eight lakh families, light up 3,000 houses and provide gas connections to 40 lakh homes," Modi stated. Referring to Mission Shakti, when India demonstrated anti-satellite (ASAT) missile capability by shooting down a live satellite, he said the government has taken measures to set up a 'chowkidar' (watchman) in space. He came down heavily on opposition parties who he said "belittled" the space achievement. "Those that are criticising the anti-satellite technology will be given a befitting reply in the elections," he claimed, urging people to vote for a government that can take concrete decisions, not the one that only raises slogans. Yoga Day.description: The world marks the fifth edition of International Day of Yoga on June 21, 2019. Prime Minister Narendra Modi hosted the main event in Ranchi and performed yoga along with 18,000 people. It was on September 27, 2014 that PM Modi proposed a dedicated day for Yoga to the United Nations General Assembly (UNGA). In 2015, the first International Day of Yoga was observed. Here's a look at different yoga styles and its growing popularity worldwide. Download The Times of India News App for Latest India News.

Survey report debunks Nagpur\u2019s logi.description: NAGPUR: Amid much hype over Nagpur emerging as the country’s warehousing hub in the Goods and Service Tax (GST) regime, a report by Knight Frank, an international research agency, has discounted the theory. Even as the logistics sector has grown by 77% in 2018, Nagpur is yet to find a place in India’s warehousing map, it says. The report also says that Nagpur’s emergence as a warehousing hub remains uncertain, due to its lack of proximity to any major consumption centre. The report was released on Wednesday. Nagpur was chosen for the study considering the hype and also the recent developments in terms of infrastructure carried out here. Knight Frank’s report, which studied a number of major areas like Ahmedabad, Kolkata, Hyderabad and NCR, only puts Nagpur among the second rung centres in terms of warehousing business. “Despite its strategic location, the major consumption markets such as Delhi, Mumbai, Kolkata, Bengaluru and Chennai are 800 to 1,000km away from Nagpur. The tier II and tier III cities near Nagpur like Raipur, Jabalpur, Bhopal, Bhilai and Indore are far below in the pecking order from a consumption perspective. While it is still premature to write off Nagpur, its warehousing clusters are not getting organized as fast as other cities, post implementation of GST,” says the report. Pinkesh Teckwani, national director (industrial & asset services) for Knight Frank India, told TOI, “Nagpur may have a strategic advantage in terms of location but having a central warehouse under the hub and scope model here does not make a feasible business proposition for many. Logistics still constitutes almost 13% to 15% of the cost component. Given the distances from major consumption centres, bringing a warehousing set-up in Nagpur would not make a major difference in terms of cost reduction.” Centres like NCR or even Mumbai would be too far to be fed from Nagpur. NCR and Mumbai constitute almost 40% of the consumption, he said. Nagpur can, however, have regional hubs catering to locations within a distance of 300km, he said. It can also emerge as an air cargo hub but surface transport can’t be as feasible. However, a chunk of transportation remains to take place through road. The reduction in transportation may not even be compensated by lesser rentals, he said. Meanwhile, the Knight Frank report also mentions that the Mihan project is expected to attract sizeable investments for both SEZ and non-SEZ areas, due to which Nagpur can emerge as a major cargo hub. The manufacturing industry units will include those from sectors like food processing, pharmaceuticals and textiles The large-scale industrial activity is likely to give a fillip to quality warehousing business. The industrial estates of MIDC too have a major role to play in the development. Shivkumar Rao, vice-president of Vidarbha Economic Development Council (VED), said it was always proposed that Nagpur has the prospect of emerging as a regional hub. However, even that has to be facilitated by putting in place the right regulatory framework. The state had come up with a logistics policy in 2018 which remains to be implemented completely, he said. VED had been championing for Mihan since the idea was conceived. Atul Pande, president of Vidarbha Industries Association (VIA), maintained optimism about Nagpur, said that it is the apparent choice for a logistics hub. Every part of the country is almost equidistant from Nagpur and the city is well-connected by road, rail and air, he added. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

\u2018India has just 2.4% of world\u2019.description: NAGPUR: India holds only 2.4% of total land surface but we host more than 18% of the world population. So think how little we have and how much more we have to share among each other, revealed DS Meshram, president of Institute of Town Planners of India (ITPI), New Delhi, here on Monday. Dr Meshram was speaking during the second edition of lecture series on ‘Manageable Cities and it’s Determinant Factors’. The event was held by ITPI, at its hall in Trimurti Nagar, on Monday. Dr Meshram further said, “In India the land to per person ratio is 0.0024 while in the world it is 0.011.” “The main issues for the marginality disturbance are land, human and financial capital. There is no land in urban areas to develop, neither people have the finances to support anymore development,” he said. He gave an example saying, “A frog cannot grow up to the size of an elephant neither an elephant can grow to infinity, in the same way there is a limit to the expansion of cities and towns.” Main speaker of the event and director of School of Planning and Architecture, Bhopal, N Sridharan spoke about the importance of planning and people marginalized based on income, caste, space, gender, age and asset. He told about how Modi government focused on most deprived sections and has transformed lives and livelihoods. Sridharan sounded optimistic by saying that by 2031 the population would go down by 6,000 in South India. He concluded his speech by saying, “We need more planners today, than ever before.” Sujit Rodge, chairman of ITPI, Nagpur, and Sarika Bhadure were also present. (Reporting by Himesh Pande) Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

AP BJP List 2019.description: NEW DELHI: The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), on Thursday, announced its first candidate list for the Lok Sabha elections 2019 that includes 184 candidates. The party has named two candidates from Andhra Pradesh in the first list. Kanna Lakshminarayana will contest from Narasaraopet Lok Sabha constituency while D Purandeshwari will contest from the Visakhapatnam seat. Andhra Pradesh will go to polls in a single phase on April 11. BJP's Lok Sabha first full list The Lok Sabha elections will be held in seven phases from April 11 to May 19, 2019. The counting of the votes has been scheduled for May 23. The first phase will be held on April 11, second on April 18, third on April 23 and fourth on April 29, fifth on May 6, sixth on May 12 and seventh phase on May 19. Prime Minister Narendra Modi will contest from Varanasi constituency, while BJP president Amit Shah will fight from Gandhinagar in place of L K Advani. As many as 90 crore electors, including 1.59 crore new voters aged 18-19 years, are registered to vote in the upcoming general election. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Lok Sabha Elections in Tamil Nadu.description: NEW DELHI: Tamil Nadu goes to polls in the second phase of the seven-phase elections. Elections to 39 parliamentary seats will take place on April 18 in a single-phase polling. Lok Sabha elections 2019: Get all live updatesTOP CONTENDERSThe four-cornered contest features AIADMK-led National Democratic Alliance (NDA), its chief rival DMK-led Secular Progressive Alliance (SPA), actor Kamal Haasan's Makkal Needhi Maiam and TTV Dhinakaran's Amma Makkal Munnetra Kazhagam (AMMK). This time the elections are taking place sans the Dravidian stalwarts M Karunanidhi and J Jayalalithaa. AIADMK chief Jayalalithaa passed away in December 2016 while Karunanidhi died in August 2018. While the DMK is contesting on 20 seats, the Congress is fighting elections on 9 seats in Tamil Nadu. In the AIADMK-BJP alliance, the national party will be contesting from five seats in the state while the PMK will be contesting from seven. Tamil Nadu Lok Sabha elections: Get all live updatesHOW MANY SEATS?Tamil Nadu has 39 Lok Sabha seats and one in neighbouring Puducherry. NMC may lose 163 marks for potholes in S.description: NAGPUR: The next round of Swachh Survekshan is likely to see Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) lose marks due to potholes on roads. NMC has received a kit for the 2020 Swachh Bharat Survekshan, which has three broad parameters; infrastructure availability, maintenance of road premises and equipment, and feedback from commuters for rating roads on overall cleanliness, under the Swachh Bharat Survey. Bad roads or potholed roads would cost NMC 163 marks. In 2019, Nagpur city stood 58th in the Swachh survey. This means NMC will not only have to make the roads free of potholes but also keep them well maintained through the monsoon. Even open water drainage system will account for four marks. Lack of zebra crossings or stop lines will cost the civic body another four marks. Non-functioning or poor maintenance of traffic signals will also cost four marks. Encroachment on footpaths and lack of traffic signs weighs for eight marks. In recent years, NMC earned a dubious distinction for bad roads and poor maintenance of traffic signals. Civic activist and secretary of Vidarbha Taxpayers Association (VTA) Tejinder Singh Renu admitted that Nagpur will face an extreme challenge due to new parameters of Swachh infrastructure. “As a majority of roads in Nagpur are under construction, our current roads condition, water drainage, street markings and cleanliness is certainly not up to the mark. Therefore, maintaining our position will be a big challenge for city administration,” he pointed out. “I believe such change of parameters by ministry of urban development is deliberate so that all city administrations concentrate on road conditions, which need to be good with the monsoon around the corner. Bad roads in the rainy season makes road usage extremely dangerous, especially for two-wheeler users,” he added. Our city administration needs to be strict about contractors, including those of MSRDC, NHAI and NIT, as roads are not repaired even after other work is completed. The service roads are in a pathetic condition, which makes riding absolutely miserable during monsoon. “If roads are not made motorable soon, I fear a drastic drop in city’s rating in next Swachh Bharat rankings,” he said. Another challenge for NMC this year will be to remain on its toes through the year, as from this year Swachh Bharat assessment would be undertaken on a quarterly basis. This move comes after many cities slipped, and were not able to maintain hygiene once they got a decent ranking on cleanliness levels in the previous Swachh surveys, and NMC was no exception. The quarterly rank of cities will play a crucial role in their annual ranking in Swachh Survekshan 2020 because of the 25% weight given to the quarterly assessment, said the official. The annual assessment will be conducted between January and February 2020, he said. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Traffic cop held with liquor, dismissed.description: NAGPUR: Traffic constable Sachin Hande, attached to Sitabuldi division, was dismissed from service by the Joint commissioner of police Ravindra Kadam on Tuesday. He was earlier caught, along with one Pranav Mhaisekar, by Chandrapur police near Nanduri toll naka on June 9 while ferrying foreign liquors in a car in the dry district. Hande and Mhaisekar were arrested by Warora police of Chandrapur district after seizing two cartons of liquor in their car. The car was driven by Mhaisekar. Hande, who was in uniform despite being a holiday, had tried to mislead the cops. Warora police was also granted two days of custody remand by the court for detailed investigation. It’s learnt that the car was in the name of Mhaisekar’s mother who is a medical practitioner too. City police top brass, after receiving the official reports from their Chandrapur counterparts, decided to invoke the powers granted to competent authority under article 311 (2) (B) of the Indian constitution to remove Hande from service for maligning the image of the department. The city police also cited the nexus of Hande with criminals and racketeers as the other reason for his dismissal. Another ground, proposed to dismiss Hande, was that he may influence, threaten and intimidate the witnesses if any inquiry is instituted against him. Revival hopes gone, helpless orange grow.description: Nagpur: Hopes of a shower quickly wane as the partially cloudy sky clears in no time. “It’s been like this since 2-3 days,” says Ashok Kharade, an orange grower in his 70s, looking upwards as workers prepare to carry away the chopped wood on a trailer from his 20-acre farm. Drought has left the 700 trees of his orchard sapped beyond revival. He has no choice but to mow them down. The trees would have bore fruit for another 15 years had there been enough water, he says. The well in his farm has touched rock bottom and the water that trickles is only enough to keep the new plantation alive, which would take another four years to bear fruit. In his decades of experience in the orange belt of Katol taluka, 60km from Nagpur, Kharade says times were never so tough. Scores of trees of the famed Nagpur orange and sweet lime (mosambi) also grown side by side, have withered away due to lack of water. The trees bear fruits during summer and have to be irrigated till its rains to get a sizeable harvest in September-October. Two years of deficient rains have left water resources depleted. Water wasn’t released for irrigation from the nearby Jam project, say locals. With even farm wells exhausted, for those like Kharade the only option is to cut down the trees. He plans to grow cotton on the land and plant orange or mosambi saplings only a year later. The orchard earned him around Rs2 lakh a year. “I can manage because my sons work and farming is not the sole means of livelihood,” he says. Clearing the orchards has cost him Rs50,000 and the wood that has no other use except fuel may fetch Rs4,000, says Kharade. “Others are not so lucky. A majority of the growers depend solely on agriculture. Farmers are managing to get water even by deploying tankers to keep the trees alive. However, about half of the orange trees in the area have died. The situation is worse in other pockets like Warud in Amravati,” says Manoj Jawanjal, a director in Maha Orange, an orange growers’ association. There is a likelihood of a major dip in area under orange this year. The government should promptly undertake a survey and assess the damage. A demand has been already put up at the collectorate, he says. Across the road, workers toil 65 feet below in a well. A worker Premalal climbs up the pulley. “We have been digging since a week, and may have to go further 9 feet deep to strike water. Our team has deepened 4-5 wells during this season only to get water at 70 to 75 feet depth,” he says. Even the JCB operator is a busy man with orders to raze orchards in villages around. Riding a rickety bicycle, Shankar Gawande looks desperate. Over a quarter of his orange trees have gone. With little funds, he does not plan to even cut the trees this year. “It’s a loss of almost Rs1.25 lakh. I have three sons, none earns enough,” he says. A tanker costs Rs1,000 for each round. Tankers are needed in a gap of 2-3 days. Farmers like Arun Raut have gone for tankers. “So far, I have gone for 10 rounds of watering using tankers. Hopefully, that would save the 200-odd trees I have,” he says. Patches of green orchards seen intermittently are either due to availability of ground water or tough efforts. Light showers but it is not monsoon yet.description: NAGPUR: Light rainfall on Thursday brought respite from sweltering heat in the city. According to the met department, monsoon is expected to hit Vidarbha in the next five-six days. Late in the afternoon on Thursday, Nagpur received a rainfall of 2 millimetres, bringing the maximum temperature down to 40.6 degree Celsius, which was still five degrees above normal. On Wednesday, the city recorded a maximum temperature of 41.5 degree Celsius. As per met officials, pre-monsoon showers have hit some parts of the region. “Though light, the rains can be termed as beginning of pre-monsoon showers. Monsoon has hit Goa and Konkan belt and its onset in Vidarbha is expected in soon,” said Mohanlal Sahu, deputy director of Regional Meteorological Centre (RMC), Nagpur. As per RMC data, Amravati received the highest rainfall in the region on Thursday at 3.1mm. Apart from this, Buldhana and Yavatmal received 0.9 and 0.7mm rains, respectively. At 42.3 degree Celsius, Bramhapuri was the hottest in the region. Maximum temperatures in Nagpur are expected to be around 40 degree Celsius for the next two days. By the start of next week, the mercury levels are expected to witness a further dip to 37-35 degree Celsius. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Arvind Kejriwal.description: VISAKHAPATNAM: Delhi chief minister Arvind Kejriwal on Monday said that Congress President Rahul Gandhi has refused to forge an alliance with the AAP for the Lok Sabha polls in the national capital. Full coverage: Lok Sabha electionsTalking to reporters at the airport here, the AAP leader said he had met Gandhi recently and the Congress leader had refused to “join hands with the AAP”. Asked about Congress' Delhi unit president Sheila Dikshit's remarks that Kejriwal never approached her for an alliance, the chief minister said, “We have met Rahul Gandhi. Dikshit is not that important leader.” Kejriwal has been urging the Congress to stitch an alliance in Delhi for the Lok Sabha polls to keep the BJP away from power. Leaders in the Delhi unit of the Congress were divided over the issue of alliance with Dikshit and her three working presidents opposing it, party sources had said. A top source in the party had recently said that chances of alliance were "slim" considering its long term repercussions in Delhi. "The biggest question is how will Congress face the AAP in Assembly elections due in 2020 after the tie up. Also, the party does not gain much politically as it is being offered only 2-3 seats by Kejriwal," the source had said. Congress had drawn a blank in the 2014 parliamentary elections in Delhi. The talk of alliance was fuelled by the fact that the Congress and AAP had jointly polled more votes than the BJP that had walked away with all the seven seats in the national capital. Delhi has 7 Lok Sabha seats and it will go to polls on May 12. Maharashtra yet to assess damage.description: NAGPUR: The state government has taken no cognisance of the loss in oranges despite being aware of the situation. A group of leaders led by former MLA Ashish Deshmukh had met district collector Ashwin Mudgal more than a fortnight back and appraised him about the dwindling water scenario in orange orchards. In their representation, they had demanded 90% subsidy on drip irrigation, supply of water through tankers in highly dried areas for irrigation and advising state agriculture farmers to guide in mulching. “The collector had assured us to forward our demands to the chief minister. Unlike western Maharashtra, Vidarbha’s horticulture farmers have got no compensation for drought in areas like Kalmeshwar, Katol and Narkhed,” said Deshmukh. The state agriculture department has also not conducted any survey yet to assess the extent of the orchard drying. R Bhonsale, joint director agriculture, Nagpur division, told TOI that the survey can be done only on directions of the district collector. “We have no such instructions yet,” he said. New state agriculture minister Anil Bonde said that he took meetings of agriculture secretaries and directors, and told them to generate their own data on affected areas without depending on the revenue department. “Agriculture department officials should remain connected with farmers and always have an estimate of any losses about all crops,” he said. Though most farmers are claiming that their orchards incurred permanent damage, MS Ladaniya, the director Central Citrus Research Institute (CCRI), has denied it. “It is temporary drying. Even if a few green leaves are present on a tree, it can be revived through rain. But this is possible only in the areas where there is heavy and deep soil in orange growing areas in Morshi, Warud and Katol tehsils. Oranges in shallow and light soils will not survive such drought,” he said. Ladaniya claims that CCRI had issued advisories to orange growers to thin the fruits (remove half fruits) from trees to reduce the loss on a tree. The institute had also suggested mulching (covering of the tree bottom by grass, straw or even plastic) to prevent evaporation losses. This helps conserve water near the roots. “The state government needs to take the issue seriously. Farmers should be advised to retain moisture in soil and spend more money on it. Last monsoon had a 23% deficit. If this persists, this year too the situation will be grave. There should be a water grid for proper distribution. It is an expensive proposition but is one of the solutions,” said Ladaniya. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

MahaMetro changes devpt model for 25-sto.description: NAGPUR: In view of poor response received from bidders, MahaMetro has changed the development model of 25-storey traffic and transport management centre (TTMC) opposite Yeshwant Stadium. The building will be one of the tallest in the city after completion. Earlier, the private operator was to construct the project on its own and pay royalty to the Metro agency. However, during the pre-bid meeting, construction companies said that it would be difficult for them to obtain all clearances from agencies like Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC). MahaMetro therefore decided to construct the structure itself using the operator’s money. “We will obtain all the permissions needed for construction. The operator will pay us money in instalments. It will also do the interiors. It will start paying us royalty when it starts leasing out the property. The exact revenue model is however, being worked out,” said Brijesh Dixit, managing director of MahaMetro. Admitting that the slump in real estate market had hit the project, he said that the construction model may be changed if it does not get proper response. The project will come up on Patwardhan Ground, which is spread over an area of around 20,000 square metre. The TTMC will be connected with Sitabuldi Metro station with an elevated skywalk. Metro will provide bus connectivity and parking in the TTMC. The construction will have a floor to space index (FSI) of 4 and will be spread over 9.83 lakh square feet. Some 2.92 lakh square feet will be dedicated to free parking. One TTMC tower will be 25 storey high while the remaining two will have 19 floors. All the towers will have retail mall on ground, first and second floors and small offices on third, fourth and fifth floors. A three-level multiplex has been envisaged above fifth floor in Tower 1 and fifteen floor of offices in Towers 1 and 3. Retail mall would have online stores, food court, family entertainment centre, large format stores, supermarket, mini anchor fashion store, mini anchor for electronics and home decor, etc. The basement will be completely dedicated to parking. There will be 600 bays for parking of cars, 1,050 bays for parking of motorcycles and 1,000 slots for bicycles. L&T leased trains on CM’s request While activist Prashant Pawar had alleged that MahaMetro leased two trains from L & T, which runs the Hyderabad Metro, because it is a private company, documents obtained by TOI show otherwise. L & T was extremely reluctant to provide the two trains (six coaches) sought by MahaMetro. It was only after Maharashtra chief minister Devendra Fadnavis wrote a letter to his Telangana counterpart in May 2017 that L & T changed its decision. MahaMetro was forced to lease L & T trains because they are similar to the Nagpur Metro ones. Both have three coaches and front evacuation facility. Commissioner of Metro Rail Safety (CMRS) had asked MahaMetro to conduct trial run only with trains that are similar to the ones to be used by Nagpur Metro. L & T took advantage of this fact and charged a whopping Rs7.5 crore annual rent per train. It imposed a condition that the lease period should be four years. MahaMetro managed to reduce it to three. Newly appointed \u2018vruksha mitra\u201.description: NAGPUR: A day after ‘Vruksha Mitra’ card was handed over to green activist Mehul Kosurakar by mayor, he saved fully-grown trees which were facing the axe through illegal felling. The civic body has made 200 such appointments to encourage green lovers save urban tree cover. On a tip-off from a citizen about tree felling in Gokulpeth, Kosurakar from NGO Green Vigil Foundation reached the spot where a group of labourers were chopping branches of a fully-grown Subabul tree. On enquiring, the activist found that the tree was being cut without the mandatory permission from Nagpur Municipal Corporation’s (NMC) garden department. “The illegal activity was taking place inside the residential premises of Praful Goregaokar. When I initially tried to stop them, they got aggressive and landed into an argument. After I showed them the Vruksha Mitra card, they calmed down and left the spot,” said Kosurakar. The activist then met the house owner Goregaokar and explained to him the amended Maharashtra (Urban Trees) Protection and Preservation of Trees Act. He also alerted the NMC garden department after which a team reached on site and filed a panchnama after spot inspection. While it is not known how many trees were planned to be chopped, Kosurakar said there were Neem and few more trees in the bungalow garden. In his statement given to officials, Goregaokar stated that the trees posed a threat as they were close to overhead electric wires, a claim refuted by the green activist. The house owner has assured not to cut any more trees. Taking note of increasing practice of house owners cutting their own trees, the civic body is promulgating that citizens need permission for even trimming a tree inside their premises. To ensure public participation in saving green cover, NMC has adopted the concept of Vruksha Mitra or friend of trees which was proposed by environment NGO Nature Conservation Association. The group suggested that Vruksha Mitras can lend helping hand to the short-staffed garden department by performing certain duties like reporting about illegal tree-felling, identifying sites for tree plantations etc Mayor Nanda Jichkar said that NMC is identifying green lovers from different areas and appointing them as Vruksha Mitras. According to garden superintendent Amol Chorpagar, the duties of Vruksha Mitras will be decided soon. “We will be finalizing what powers they will hold and responsibilities they will have to carry out,” he said. Speed up DP Road construction work: Nagp.description: NAGPUR: Deputy mayor Deepraj Pardikar on Wednesday expressed anguish over the slow progress of DP Road construction from Piwli Marbat to Pachpaoli Square. Pardikar visited localities in Satranjipura zone and reviewed ongoing development works. He was shocked to find out that encroachments have hindered the road widening work. He directed the anti-encroachment department to clear the road for widening of existing DP Road. He said that the civic body has also approached the state government to sanction the road to widen it to 80ft. The move will ease congestion, Pardikar said. He also expressed concern over non-allotment of platforms in vegetable market near Naik Talao and directed the market department to complete the allotment without further delay. \nGovernment Chitrakala Mahavidyalaya ho.description: There was a flurry of excitement among the students and teaching staff of Government Chitrakala Mahavidyalaya at their recently organised cultural fiesta —Aakar—where everyone enjoyed cultural treats, entertaining acts and fun-filled competitions. The discerning audience enjoyed a fine bouquet of performing arts and shared a good time interacting with one another on this occasion.  “This fest is a melting pot of various art forms and the students have been given a great platform by the college to exhibit their talent. From traditional dance performances to skits, mono acts, painting exhibitions to food stalls, there was a fine mix of everything for people to enjoy,” said lecturer Kishore Ingale.  We spotted principal of the college Vinod Mankar and educationists Subhash Babhulkar, Vikash Joshi, Rakesh Pathrabe and Rajendra Giri having a good time at the fiesta. India Pakistan news.description: NEW DELHI/ISLAMABAD: India dismissed on Thursday as "fake news" the suggestion in Pak media that it was looking to resume talks with the hostile neighbour and asserted that there was no dilution of its position that Islamabad needed to take verifiable and irreversible action against terrorism for the dialogue to resume. Responding to Pakistan PM Imran Khan's congratulatory letter after he assumed office for the second time, PM Narendra Modi wrote back on June 12 expressing India's desire to have normal and cooperative relations with all its neighbours, including Pakistan, while stressing that "for this, it is important to build an environment of trust, free of terror, violence and hostility". Foreign minister S Jaishankar also wrote to his Pakistani counterpart S M Qureshi, again only in response to the latter's congratulatory letter, emphasising the need for an atmosphere "free from the shadow of terror and violence". The emphasis on the need for Pakistan to rein in terror as a pre-condition for re-engagement was in keeping with the stand which saw Modi refrain from engaging with Imran Khan at the just-concluded SCO summit in Kyrgyzstan. Yet, the Pakistani media chose to interpret the contents of the letters of Modi and Jaishankar as reflecting India's desire to re-engage. The foreign ministry in Delhi quickly scotched the suggestion. "There was complete distortion and an attempt to peddle fake news (in the way it was reported). The letters only reiterated India's old position that it wants normal and cooperative relations with all countries in South Asia and that it was important to create an environment free of terror and violence for it. There was no mention of any sort of dialogue with Pakistan," said MEA spokesperson Raveesh Kumar, adding that India will not be fooled by any cosmetic action against terror by Islamabad. Emphasising that both the letters were written in as per the "established diplomatic practice", Kumar said: "In their messages, they have highlighted that India seeks normal and cooperative relations with all neighbours, including Pakistan." In his letter, Modi had said that India remained committed to operationalising early an "all-year-round" Kartarpur corridor. Touching upon it, Kumar said India had already held three technical-level discussions with Pakistan and was currently awaiting clarification from Islamabad over a few issues it had raised. Puzzlingly, later in the evening, Pakistan's foreign ministry, which had kept quiet through the day, also sought to play down the speculation about the import of the letters. While responding to a question, the spokesperson said, "It was an established practice for the leadership to congratulate new office holders and for them to respond." "Pakistan's position on the way forward in relations with India was clear and well-known and did not require repetition," said the spokesperson, adding that the "vision of peace, progress and prosperity of South Asia could be advanced by peacefully resolving all outstanding disputes, including Jammu & Kashmir, and moving away from dynamic of confrontation to cooperation". Earlier in the day, sources in the Pakistan foreign office had said that Modi and Jaishankar had responded positively to recent letters from their Pakistani counterparts by conveying New Delhi's desire to engage with all countries, including Pakistan, for elimination of terrorism and prosperity of the region. "India has always prioritised peace and human development, and sought to maintain cordial relations with all regional powers," Modi and Jaishankar maintained, according to FO sources. Both leaders, according to FO sources, called for special attention on elimination of terrorism in the region and said the issue must be a core focus in all future talks. They have also appreciated sentiments from Pakistan in their letters, the FO sources added. Modi's letter was in response to a congratulatory letter from Khan in which he had underscored Pakistan's vision of working for "durable peace and stability in South Asia with peaceful resolution of all outstanding disputes, including J&K". Rare albino Eurasian coot sighted at Gor.description: NAGPUR: A rare sighting of partial albino Eurasian Coot (Fulica atra) has been reported in Gorewada lake in the city by bird watchers. “Eurasian Coot is black in colour and has a white patch on the forehead but the sighted particular individual has white feathers and some black patches. This is the first such sighting of a partial albino bird in Vidarbha,” said ornithologist and founder of Central India Bird Academy (CIBA), Dr Anil Pimplapure. The bird was sighted by Dr Pimplapure, along with Kaustubh Pandharipande, Aniruddha Bhagat in Gorewada lake on Monday morning. The bird watchers stumbled upon the bird when they had gone to see the plight of the drying Gorewada lake. Dr Pimplapure recalled such a sighting was reported at Bhigwan near Pune previously and this case is extremely rare. This stage occurs due to lack of pigmentation named melanin in the birds due to which the feathers of the bird turn white. “Melanin gives strength to feathers and protects damage to eyes due to the ultra violet rays of the sun,” he added. Dr Pimplapure further said that the lake's water level has reached the lowest since last 100 years. The sighting of this bird has delighted the city birders. Satta Market.description: BHOPAL: This assembly  is turning out to be a nail-biter. The Bhopal satta bazaar that gave BJP a good chance three weeks ago is suddenly abuzz about Congress’ prospects. As per the bookies, till about a month ago, if a person placed a bet of Rs 10,000 on BJP, he would get Rs 11,000 if the party returned to power. And anyone who bet Rs 4,400 on Congress would get Rs 10,000 if the opposition wins. This week, bookies say, they are taking bets on number of seats and not on who would form the government. “In case no party gets absolute majority, or if the scoreline is too close,” explained a bookie. “We do not want to say which party will form the government. The bets are open. The satta market is running good this poll season, as it is a thrilling contest,” he added. Bookies told TOI that satta trends may not reflect the actual situation on the ground, but the market is accepting bets on 116-plus seats for Congress and 102 or more for ruling BJP. “Anyone who bets successfully on BJP or Congress will double his money,” a bookie said, adding that this trend may change just as suddenly in the next few days as campaigning gets more intense. The same bookie had told TOI around a month ago that rates may vary once candidates are finalised by the parties, “but we expect the trend to remain the same”. The satta market runs into crores in every election. Bets are placed not just over phone, but also on websites and apps, leaving almost no room for police to track down bookies and those placing bets. Probably, this is why no gang has been busted in the state so far for running an election betting racket. At least two cases of betting are registered daily in Bhopal, but the people pulling the strings of the racket in poll season are yet to be caught. Police officers say it is getting increasingly difficult to nab such gangs because they are constantly on the move. “Online betting can be operated even from a moving car, a café or any public place anywhere in the country. Those running the betting in Bhopal may be sitting anywhere on the globe,” said an officer. SP-south Rahul Kumar Lodha said a special campaign is being run against criminals involved in gambling and betting ahead of elections. “These criminals are made to sign bonds to prevent them from committing such crimes in the future. Raids are being conducted on specific tips. A list of habitual offenders is being prepared by police stations to curb such illegal activities,” he said. ASP-crime Rashmi Mishra said the crime branch has activated its network of informers prior to elections to keep an eye on betting. “It is difficult to crack online betting and gambling rackets, but police take action against criminals on specific inputs. For instance, we were tipped off on Monday night about a betting den in Kolar. It was raided but no such activity was found,” Mishra said, adding that the cyber cell is constantly on the lookout for websites and mobile apps used by betting rackets. Water issue sparks fire in NMC general b.description: NAGPUR: The Nagpur Municipal Corporation has warned the head of the water works department to submit action taken report on water supply system within a week or face suspension. The decision came following submission of an adjournment motion in the NMC general body meeting over water crisis by senior Congress corporator Praful Gudadhe and BJP corporator Dharmpal Meshram. The general body meeting on Thursday began after a delay of 70 minutes and witnessed noisy scenes. Independents and BSP corporators staged a walkout over mayor Nanda Jichkar’s refusal to allow discussions on the issues raised by them. A war of words also erupted between the ruling and opposition members over not allowing corporators to seek information over the issues raised by them. The city had witnessed low rainfall last year. With a view to streamline water supply across the city this summer, the general body had instructed the administration to prepare an action taken report regarding the measures it would take to ensure proper supply during summer. During the period, Gudadhe had alleged unequal distribution of water in the city. “Many areas were getting around the clock water, while numerous localities were deprived of even a bucket of potable water,” Gudadhe had claimed. However, even after six months of being instructed to table ATR, the administration had no report to table before the House despite the opposition parties repeatedly raising the issue and reminding the ruling party in the last general body meetings held in January and February. Gudadhe also alleged that the NMC supplied almost 740mld per day before the Lok Sabha elections, which has now come down significantly. The administration failed to give a satisfactory reply to Gudadhe’s query. WWD executive engineer Shweta Banerjee admitted that now the NMC is supplying 670mld to 680mld daily. Independent corporator Abha Pande tore up the agenda of NMC general body to protest mayor Nanda Jichkar’s decision not to allow discussion on water scarcity in the city that was on the agenda raised by her. She charged Jichkar with dictatorial attitude in conducting the House. Pande will now stage ‘Jal Tyag Andolan’ along with her supporters at 11.30am on Friday. Congress corporator Harish Gwalbanshi raised water works department’s lackadaisical approach to de-silt Gorewada lake. He also alleged that though the NMC hired two excavators for de-silting the lake, the work was yet to start. The civic body should take the advantage of dry bed of the lake as it would help the NMC to ensure better water storage in the coming years, he pointed out. BSP corporator Jitendra Ghodeswar raised the issue of many localities in North Nagpur were receiving contaminated tap water. Senior Congress corporator Manoj Sangole suggested the NMC should use well water for fire tenders and de-choking machines. Leader of opposition Tanaji Wanve sought the mayor to direct the administration to lodge police complaints against Orange City Water for ignoring leakages in pipelines and failing to resolve water contamination issues. The general body directed the civic administration to check whether the civic body has power to take action against RO plants selling water in cans after Wanve raised the issue of illegal operation of the plants in the city. According to him, there are over 100s RO plants, while zones of the civic body had issued only 21 no-objection certificates. Most of the RO plants were selling contaminated water, he claimed. Four end life in different incidents.description: NAGPUR: Four suicides, including one of a senior citizen, were reported at different locations in city on Wednesday. In all the incidents, police have registered the cases currently as accidental death and have launched a probe. In the first incident, wedding day celebration of a family turned sorrowful after the groom’s younger brother committed suicide at home while his family was attending the function. Sanket Bahadure, 24, was found hanging at his house by some electricians in Itwari area. In another incident, Haridas Wankhede, 65, was found hanging from iron railing of Chikhli Bridge on Wednesday at Kalamna area. Haridas, a resident of Adiwasi Prakash Nagar, was spotted by some passers-by who informed Kalamna police. In the third incident, Pandhari Meshram, 57, committed suicide by hanging himself to the ceiling fan at his home at Nildoh. Cops said Meshram’s wife Kunda was out talking with neighbours when he took the drastic step. In the final case, Sanjay Ohariya, 35, committed suicide by hanging himself to an iron pipe with a sari in the basement of an under construction building at Ganeshpeth. According to cops, Sanjay who hailed from Madhya Pradesh, had come to city to work as a labour. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

A career tailormade for those with style.description: A fashion designer applies art devoted to design, aesthetics and natural beauty to clothing and its accessories. The field of fashion designing is influenced by cultural and social attitudes and varies with time and place. It is an alluring avenue with a high quotient of glamour and appeal. City's leading designer in men's wear, Dhruv Hingle, believes that a penchant for fashion is a precursor for one to flourish in this profession. He says, “Fashion designers need to adapt to the dynamic trends in fashion. This field demands an instinct for creativity with a blend of originality and style. A career in fashion designing is tailor made for you if you have the right choice of colour combinations.” Fashion designers need to be updated with the basic principles that can help them add innovation and style to completely transform a seemingly dull wardrobe. The natural skill set comprising of a decent aesthetic sense, colour expertise, good taste, an eye for detail and knowledge of fabrics is a bonus. Fashion designers need to combine their creativity with managerial skills to sustain in this industry. Many institutions provide training to potential fashion designers to expand their talent and become entrepreneurs in the fashion world. Acquired skills can be obtained by a qualification from a recognized fashion institute. You can enrol for either a full-time or a part time certificate course. There are several short-term certificate courses that are offered by fashion institutes for specialization. These courses equip one with technical and creative thinking skills. India is progressing rapidly in the fashion industry owing to available labour and excellent craftsmanship. The scope for fashion designing jobs in the country is immense as Indians have increasingly become fashion conscious and seek to enhance it in every way. Apparel companies need to hire people for a variety of jobs, ranging from fashion designers, textile designers, models, retailers, buyers and merchandizers to provide end-to-end solutions to their clients. In addition, there is a growing demand and the scope for Indian fashion in international markets has broadened. Fashion designers have the opportunity to wear different hats in areas like designer wear production, fashion marketing, planning and concept management. You can work as a designated costume designer, fashion consultant, personal stylist, technical designer, graphic designer, production pattern maker or a fashion coordinator. Those interested in a career in fashion designing can also become entrepreneurs and start their own companies. Maintaining a portfolio that showcases your creative talents and an apprenticeship under a well-known designer is desirable for getting hired in this industry. You can foray into this market thorough research. 2. WHY OPT FOR THE SUBJECT? · Fame, glamour and popularity · Field boasts of a lucrative income · One can be a trendsetter · Requires minimum formal education · Entrepreneurial ventures can be pursued · Exciting and stimulating work environment 3. Expert View: Shruti Sancheti ‘Creativity and flair for the craft are a must’ Fashion design as a career option is one of the most coveted but often the most misunderstood. People associate it with glamour and consider it frivolous but it is an industry worth 2.4 trillion dollars with a growth rate of 5.5% annually and contributes greatly to the GDP of any economy and is a serious profession which entails a lot of hard work and dedication. Fashion designing as a vocation requires inherent creativity and a flair for craft but that is not enough. Any student wanting to pursue this field must know that the prerequisites are hard work, dedication, constant innovation and keeping oneself updated and aware of not only fashion trends but also world affairs and events. The course itself covers about 30 subjects in a span of three years where everything from sketching to the making of garments to marketing them and the management of business along with world history, basics of fashion to French are taught and for a student to excel in this deeply competitive field, he has to be proficient in all subjects. One has to understand that this profession is about the 4 Cs of fashion — cut, colour, construction, cost — along with the 4 Ps of marketing — product, price, promotion and place along with strong research and development. Fashion is not just an art. One has to deeply understand commerce to become eminent and unparalleled in this competitive field. Every student who studies fashion has to understand that starting a label in not the only option. There are many other challenging and lucrative avenues open to a student of fashion like fashion merchandizer, fashion photography, visual merchandizer, textile designer, product designer, graphic designer, footwear, knitwear, styling, fashion make-up, fashion choreographer, personal shopper and many more. The possibilities are unlimited and one has to be prepared to work sincerely and unwaveringly towards one‘s goals and be totally original, different and yet focused and determined and even if one can’t do different things, try to do them differently and grab all opportunities as opportunities dance with those who are on the dance floor. (Shruti Sancheti is fashion designer and fashion faculty) Expert view Abdul Zubair Fashion is forward looking and cyclical Fashion designing is the art of applying design, aesthetics and natural beauty to clothing and its accessories. This art is influenced by cultural and social attitudes and has evolved over time and place. Fashion designers attempt to design clothes which are functional as well as aesthetically pleasing. They consider who is likely to wear the garment as well as the occasions. They work within a wide range of material, colours, patterns and styles. The scope of fashion designing is wide in both India and abroad. Students have innumerable choices in front of them after completing their professional studies in fashion designing. Fashion designers have varied options including designing, research, cloth production, textile designing, fashion merchandises, fashion stylists, fashion photography, entrepreneur etc. Fashion has always been a hotbed for innovation, from invention of sewing machine to rise of e-commerce. Like technology, fashion is forward looking and cyclical. Today, technology is transforming fashion at a faster pace than ever. From robots that sew and cut fabrics to AI algorithms that predict style trends to VR mirrors in dressing rooms, technology is automating, personalizing and speeding up every aspect of fashion. The fashion market in India is currently estimated at USD 70 billion. Though a handful of designers existed prior to 1980s, the late 80s and 90s saw a spurt. This was the result of increasing exposure to global fashion and economic boom after economic liberalization in 1991. It is the most glamorous field. It does not require creative thinking, but a lucrative and growth-oriented mind. Fashion designing is one of the fields that creates high-paying jobs in India for deserving creative artists. (Zubair is managing director of IIDT) 4. List of Colleges 1) Institute of Innovative Design and Technology (IIDT) Courses offered: BSc in fashion technology, MSc in fashion designing, MBA in fashion designing Duration: Three years for BSc, two years for MSc and two years for MBA Procedure: Direct admission Source: College administration desk 2) National Institute of Fashion Technology (NIFT), Mumbai Courses offered: Bachelors in fashion design (BFD), Master of fashion management Duration: Three years and two years Procedure: NIFT entrance exam plus interview Source: College website 3) National Institute of Design (NID) Courses offered: B. Des, M. Des Duration: Four years for B. Des, 2.5 yrs for M. Des Procedure: Entrance test (DAT) + GDPI Source: College website 4) Pearl Academy, Mumbai Courses offered: UG course in fashion design, PG course in fashion design Duration: Four years for UG course, two years for PG course Procedure: Pearl entrance exam Source: College website (This list is not exhaustive and should not be considered as the endorsement of the institute. Students are advised to check with relevant education authorities before taking admission) 5. PROFESSIONALS SPEAK Fashion designing as a career is growing and the specialization in it has been seen in the past few years. It is very nice to see that the youth of today are more versatile in choosing their careers instead of following the orthodox regime of society MAHISHA MEHER The youth who are about to choose fashion designing as a career are always welcome. Fresh blood in every profession is appreciated and the future of this particular field looks bright TANISHA GARG Fashion designing is definitely growing. It is not uncommon to hear of designers who represent India in Milan or the Paris fashion week. We should be proud that we Indians are born creative and have a bright career in this field ADITI LOHIA Designing is an art and is driven by passion and love. One should not generalize fashion. A close study of the industry and making a few changes can help one to create magic with every concept CHETNA DIXIT Being a fashion designer is a dream come true and I encourage the youth to consider this field as a career option. Fashion designing is a very vast and exciting industry. In this profession, one never gets bored SHIKHA THUTHEJA (Compiled by Manshika Vaikkath, Anchal Bhatia, Shristi Sankrit & Amrit Parida) Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Satta Matka 2018.description: AGRA: Shyam Vohra, known as 'satta king' of the Taj city, was denied bail by district court of Agra. Vohra, who was arrested by the Agra police in July for his alleged involvement in betting on FIFA World Cup matches. Earlier, in April, Vohra was arrested by the Nodia STF from Greater Noida for placing bets on IPL matches, but he was granted bail. After Vohra’s arrest, Agra police booked him and his known associates including his son Vatsal, wife Rakhi, nephew Prateek, brother-in-law Kaushal and others for their alleged involvement in betting. On Monday, judge Anil Kumar Pundhir rejected Vohra’s bail plea, who was charged for attempt to murder, as he allegedly opened fire on policemen. Further, Vohra was charged for running illegal gambling racket, criminal conspiracy and obstructing policemen from executing their duties. Police are yet to arrest the relatives and associates of Vohra. Several years back, Vohra had gain notoriety for betting on cricket matches. In April, during IPL matches, the gambling racket run by Vohra had deposited Rs 62 lakh in 10 banks, after which police approached banks to freeze the amount. Even during the FIFA World Cup, Vohra collected huge amount of cash through betting. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Mamata Banerjee.description: VISAKHAPATNAM: Projecting TDP supremo and AP chief minister N Chandrababu Naidu as a “national leader of importance” and keeping the debate on the alternate front prospects in the ensuing elections alive, West Bengal chief minister and Trinamool Congress chief Mamata Banerjee appealed to people of AP to elect TDP again to keep the duo of Narendra Modi and Amit Shah away from power. “Who is Modi to ask about our Prime Minister candidate? We will decide who to elect our leader as there will be alternative for Modi,” she pointed out. Mamata said Naidu has done a lot for development of Andhra Pradesh. “It’s a necessity for AP people to give the power to Naidu again as he will play a key role in national politics and show a path of development to the entire country,” she added. Addressing a public meeting convened by TDP on Sunday, Mamata said Naidu is the leader to take the country forward. “Like he has done in Andhra Pradesh, Naidu can do a lot in Delhi,” she said. Coming down heavily on Modi, Mamata appealed the gathering to save the country and remove Modi (desh ko bachana hai to Modi ko hatao). “Modi claimed to be chaiwala after 2014 elections. Now he says he is chowkidar,” she added. “But chowkidar for whom? For those who looted the country. Modi had claimed that demonitisation would mitigate terrorism and stop black money, but ironically the number of terrorist attacks was the highest in the past two years. Under Modi’s regime, more number of farmers committed suicide and unemployment increased.” She added that Modi failed to explain the Pulawama incident and the Rafale deal and spurned the demand for an all-party meeting on the issues. “The nation does not want leaders like Narendra Modi and Amit Shah,” she asserted, and challenged Modi for an open debate on a national channel of his choice to discuss issues facing the country. Download The Times of India News App for Latest Elections News.

Maharashtra govt to give compensation to.description: WARDHA: The state government is moving to give compensation to the 8-year-old boy of Matang community, who suffered burns on being forced to sit on hot tiles as punishment after entering a temple at Arvi last week. Aryan Khadse (8), a resident of Rani Laxmibai Ward of Arvi town was accused of stealing some coins from the Jogna Mata temple in the same locality by accused Umesh alias Amol Dhore. The accused punished Aryan by forcing him to sit on hot tiles on Saturday afternoon, which caused serious burn injuries on his buttocks. NCP leader Ajit Pawar drew attention of the assembly to the episode, saying the incident is shameful and raises doubts about progressive Maharashtra. The government should do something strict to curb such incidents in future, he said. Wardha BJP MP Ramdas Tadas visited the civil hospital at Wardha, where the boy has been shifted for treatment. He said, “I spoke to the boy and he is still in fear about the incident. I consoled him and told his parents not to worry. I will personally look into the case and the accused will be not let free.” District collector Vivek Bhimanwar said, “We have arrested the accused and an inquiry is going on. The facts will come out after the inquiry. I just signed files to help the boy and his family economically for his treatment expenses.” Civil surgeon C Madavi said, “The boy is healing now, and he will be in hospital for a week. After his treatment ends, we will discharge him.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

BJP List 2019 Maharashtra.description: AURANGABAD/KOLHAPUR: Sitting MPs Sunil Gaikwad (Latur) and Dilip Gandhi (Ahmednagar) were denied tickets for the forthcoming Lok Sabha elections in the BJP’s first national list of candidates announced on Thursday. The list included 16 names from Maharashtra. While speculations were rife that the party would not retain Gaikwad owing to his differences with some senior BJP leaders, what came as a surprise was the ticket going to Sudhakar Shrungare, a member of the Latur zilla parishad. However, Shrungare, who is in the construction business, was the popular choice of local BJP workers. Gaikwad had won the 2014 election by a majority of over 2.5 lakh votes. Considered to be close to Union minister Nitin Gadkari, he was reportedly at loggerheads with Latur district guardian minister Sambhaji Patil-Nilangekar. The nomination of Sujay Vikhe Patil, son of senior Congress leader Radhakrishna Vikhe Patil, from Ahmednagar instead of Gandhi was a foregone conclusion ever since he joined the party last week. Sujay, a neurosurgeon by profession, will be making his entry into politics with this nomination. His late grandfather, Balasaheb Vikhe Patil, was long associated with the Congress. | Full coverage of Lok Sabha elections in MaharashtraAmong other prominent leaders from Maharashtra in the first list of candidates are Union minister Nitin Gadkari from his hometown Nagpur, state BJP chief Raosaheb Danve from Jalna, Union MoS Hansraj Ahir from Chandrapur and Union MoS for defence Subash Bhamre from Dhule. Late BJP MP Gopinath Munde’s daughter, Pritam, who was elected to Parliament with a record majority after her father’s death, has been renominated from Beed. Sitting MP from Sangli Sanjay Patil has also been renominated, putting an end to speculation over any change in constituency. Patil’s candidature was opposed by a section of BJP leaders in Sangli. However, chief minister Devendra Fadnavis is understood to have called a meeting of local party leaders and resolved the differences. The party has also given tickets to Heena Gavit from Nandurbar, Raksha Khadse from Raver, Poonam Mahajan from Mumbai North Central, Kapil Patil from Bhiwandi, Sanjay Dhotre from Akola, Ramdas Tadas from Wardha, Ashok Nete from Gadchiroli and Gopal Shetty from Mumbai North. SEBC ordinance: SC seeks state response.description: Nagpur: A division bench of the Supreme Court comprising justices Deepak Gupta and Surya Kant on Wednesday directed the Maharashtra government to file a reply by Monday on the special leave petition (SLP) filed by aggrieved post graduate medical students. After the Nagpur bench of Bombay High Court rejected their plea, students from the city have once again knocked the Supreme Court’s doors for justice. On June 13, the HC bench consisting of justices Sunil Shukre and Shreeram Modak rejected the petition filed by Dr Sagar Sarda, Dr Sameer Deshmukh and other PG aspirants challenging Maharashtra government’s ordinance for 16% seats under SEBC quota for Maratha students. The Maharashtra State Reservation (of seats for admission in educational institutions in the State and for appointments in the public services and posts under the State) for Socially and Educationally Backward Classes (Amendment and Validation) Ordinance, 2019, was promulgated to supersede HC’s and SC’s verdicts that had quashed the SEBC quota for PG medical seats in state. Senior counsels Shekhar Naphade and Meenakshi Arora, assisted by Hrishikesh Chitale and Ashwin Deshpande pleaded for the petitioners. They contended that the HC refused to hear their plea due to SC’s orders or June 4 where it had prohibited all courts from hearing any case related to this vexed issue. They pointed out that SEBC Act, which was actually implemented from November 30, was also under challenge in HC’s principal bench in Mumbai. The SC judges clarified that it can’t just leave the petitioners “remedy-less” as either HC or SC had to adjudicate the issue. They pointed out that SC itself had directed the petitioners to approach the Nagpur bench for relief. In their plea, the PG aspirants pointed out that HC had refused to entertain their contentions citing top court’s orders of June 4 and 10. They argued that the SEBC ordinance was contrary to the law set by the SC and prayed for its quashing. According to them, the ordinance is clearly an attempt to nullify the HC’s May 2 judgement that was later upheld by the SC. It’s also an effort to circumvent the apex court’s directives that amounts to interfering with its order. They were been prejudiced by the ordinance of illegally applying reservation and thus depriving them of benefit of the HC and SC orders. The ordinance is thus contrary to the law laid down by SC and deserves to be set aside. Both Sarda and Deshmukh had filed first petition in the Nagpur bench where they had challenged 16% SEBC quota in the PG medical seats, which was quashed by the bench comprising justices Sunil Shukre and Pushpa Ganediwala on May 2. While clarifying that the SEBC quota would be made applicable from the next academic year only, the HC had declared provisional PG seats matrix of March 27 that had a provision for SEBC candidates as “illegal”. Association wants CM to hold meet with o.description: Nagpur: Maha-Orange, an orange growers’ association, has called upon chief minister Devendra Fadnavis to take up the issue of drying of orchards due to drought in Vidarbha seriously and hold a meeting with farmers at the earliest. Shridhar Thakre, one of its directors, has written to the CM and appraised him of the situation. The letter states that orange, mousambi and lemon farmers in Vidarbha are struggling to keep their orchards alive in the extended summer with temperatures hovering above 45 degrees for a long time. “Over 50% of the orchards have dried up and the rest are wilting. We are facing economic crisis. The government needs to conduct a survey to assess the damage immediately,” the letter states. The letter adds that Vidarbha farmers have generally been very “submissive and do not have an agitating mentality”. “Hence, the government must call for a meeting soon to understand their problems, assess the damage and award compensation,” it says. Agriculture minister Anil Bonde told TOI that preliminary damage reports have pegged the loss at 30,000 hectares in Amravati district and 2,000 hectares in Nagpur district. “I have asked the agriculture department to prepare a proposal about the damage and rejuvenation at the earliest. We will need support from the relief and rehabilitation department before announcing any compensation,” said Bonde. Nagpur Zilla Parishad (ZP) president Nisha Sawarkar told TOI that the ZP general body meeting passed a resolution demanding compensation for the farmers whose orchards had dried up.
